subject: Law
title: Double Jeopardy
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Double Jeopardy.

hook.text: A man is acquitted of murder. New DNA evidence proves his guilt. Can he be retried? The Fifth Amendment says no.

buildup.text: Double jeopardy prevents being tried twice for the same offense after an acquittal or conviction.

discovery.text: The protection attaches once the jury is sworn in or the first witness testifies in a bench trial.

twist.text: The 'separate sovereigns' exception: state and federal governments can each prosecute the same conduct separately.

climax.text: This exception allowed federal civil rights charges after state acquittals in cases like Rodney King.

punchline.text: You can't be tried twiceâ€”unless two governments want to try.
